title: Restoring the Death Penalty and Protecting Public Safety

enrichment.summary: This executive order directs the Department of Justice to aggressively pursue and enforce the federal death penalty for serious crimes, especially murder of law enforcement officers and crimes committed by illegal aliens. It aims to end moratoriums on executions, support state capital punishment efforts, seek overruling of limiting Supreme Court decisions, and enhance prosecutions to protect public safety.
potential_concerns: Increased use of the death penalty may raise concerns about fairness, potential wrongful convictions, and disparate impacts on marginalized groups.
The focus on prosecuting crimes committed by illegal aliens could exacerbate tensions around immigration enforcement and civil rights.
Efforts to override Supreme Court precedents might lead to prolonged legal battles and uncertainty in capital punishment policy.
The order's strong dismissal of judicial objections could weaken the checks and balances on executive and prosecutorial power.
Prioritizing capital punishment could divert resources from other public safety and crime prevention strategies.
